dict.string: Outputs true only if all of its inputs are also true.
A mathematical logic that knows just two numbers: true—one—and false—zero. "And", "Or", and "Not" are essential for calculating with boolean algebra. It is fundamental to digital electronics.
Outputs true if its input is false and vice versa.
Outputs true if at least one of its inputs is true.
Here: Anything that can be part of a circuit, e.g. wires, gates, …

Logic gates like "and", "or" as well as inverters have a little delay between inputs and outputs. In this simulation, 100 ms need to pass before an output updates, wheras in reality, this delay may vary and be just a few nanoseconds.
Connecting the output of something to its input, making its next output also depend on the previous output.
